lines.text: He's so conspicuous he's embarassing.
Oh, that reminds me, George. Did you twist that young fellow Mostyn's tail, by any chance?
Whatever do you mean?
Yes, I thought so. That's why I sacked him. Tried to sell him to the BBC, but they wouldn't have him. What's he up to now, Strickland?
He's in retreat, sir. Joined an order of Franciscan monks near Ipswich.
Ipswich, eh? Cold bloody spot to pray.
Oh dammit, George, that whole era is dead.
And so is Vladimir! And I wish to God we'd got half his courage and one tenth his integrity.
You want a picture of Karla, George? I get you one more up to date than that, authentic provenance, no question.
Thank you, Toby. I'm only interested in the original.
Grigoriev has a salad. She has steak and chips, glass of beer, and a slice of cake. George, the guy will fold, believe me! You never had a wife like that.
No, I don't think I ever did.
You think he wants to be locked up in a two-room flat in Moscow with that bitch for the rest of his life? Ha hah, don't worry.
I'm still on the side of the angels.
I didn't know we had any angels.

First we'd take the document to Max. That's you, George. Max would know its meaning, Max would reward us. Gifts, promotion, medals, maybe we'd get lunch with the Queen. Only problem was, Vladimir didn't know you were on the shelf and the Circus had joined the Boy Scouts.

You remember the first rule of retirement, George? No moonlighting, no fooling with loose ends, no private enterprise, ever. You remember who preaches this rule, at Sarratt, in the corridors? George Smiley did. Quote, "When it's over, it's over. Pull down the shutters, go home," unquote. We're over, George. We've got no license. They don't want us anymore.
[Lacon is handling an antique book on Smiley's desk]
Oliver, would you mind leaving that alone? It's not mine, and it's worth half the gross national product.
Funny about children. Beggars keep you awake when they're there, and when they're not you can't sleep.
What was it you used to say? "I wouldn't trust Saul Enderby any further than I could throw Oliver Lacon."
[Smiley sees Peter Guillam's Porsche for the first time]
What a perfectly revolting little car! How ever will we all fit in?
Don't do that again, you hear me?
I don't speak to scum like you! What are you, a Polish? Magyar? I don't speak to anti-Party elements! I am Russian!
Don't do it again.

George, do me a favor, okay? You want a Hungarian babysitter someday, call me. You go messing around with creeps like Kirov and Leipzig, you better have a creep like Toby look after you. You're an old spy in a hurry, George. You used to say they were the worst.
Oh they are, Toby, they are.
Do they get a special price, too?
For George, they do it for nothing.

Grigorieva got herself a driving license two months ago. And she's terrible! Terrible, like lousy. You know what Pauli Skordeno says to me? He says, "Toby, I need danger money just to follow that woman."
The Grigorievs left their house five minutes ago. She's driving. Most likely they die before they get here.
Did she drive last week?
Also the week before. She insists. George, that woman is a monster.
You're very piano, Peter.
I'm just feeling my age.
All right so far, everyone? Peter? Still stumbling along behind me, are you?
I think so, sir.
How's marriage?
Blissful, thank you, sir.
Give it three years.
Why do you never make love to me, Uncle Anton? You can, you know.
You are terrorists! But if you are terrorists, why don't you bind my eyes? Why do you let me see your faces? You must cover them! I want no knowledge of you! I demand! I demand!
You are Counselor Anton Grigoriev of the Soviet Embassy in Bern, yes?
Grigoriev? I am Grigoriev. Yes, well done! I am Grigoriev! And who are you, please? Al Capone? Who are you? And why do you rumble at me like a commissar?
Then, Counselor, since we cannot afford to delay, I suggest you study the incriminating photographs on the table beside you.
George, all your life! Fantastic!
[reading a spy's confession]

"Karla's signal referred me to several émigré families who might be persuaded by pressure to adopt such an agent as their own child, since blackmail is considered preferable to bribery." Damn right it is.
[lifts his glass]
Cheers. At the present rate of inflation, blackmail's about the only thing that keeps its value.
Well, why doesn't he dig up his treasure? Put it somewhere else and cover his traces? The shit's in the fan, he knows that, Kirov's confessed!
Perhaps the treasure refuses to be moved. Perhaps Karla's options have run out.
It's daylight madness to leave that Swiss bank account intact!
It was daylight madness to use a fool like Kirov. It was madness to approach Ostrakova, and madness to believe that by killing three people he could stop the leak.
It's simply a question of whether your Service wants the product. I can't see that anything else is ultimately of very much importance.

Can't you, by God! Oh, I want him all right. I want the Mona Lisa, and the Chairman of the Chinese People's Republic, and next year's winner of the Irish Sweep. I want Karla sitting in the hot seat at Sarratt, coughing out his life story to the inquisitors. I want the American Cousins to eat out of my hand for years to come. I want the whole ball game, of course I do.
[on Grigoriev]
So which way will he jump when we hit him?

Burning, George, that's always a hazard, know what I mean? Some guys get heroic and want to die for their countries suddenly. Other guys roll over and lie still the moment you put the arm on them. Burning, that touches the stubbornness in certain people.

[about Otto Leipzig]
And he had a partner, yes that comes back to me too. An immigrant. An East German.

Hm! Worse than East German. Saxon. Name of Kretzschmar. First name Claus, with a "C". Don't ask me why. I mean these guys have no logic at all. Claus Kretzschmar was also a creep. Blond creep, lot of muscles.
But that was long ago, Toby.
Who cares? It was a perfect marriage.

[to himself]
Then I expect it didn't last.

George, listen to me. So, Ann gave you a bad time with Bill Haydon? So there's Karla, who was Bill's big daddy in Moscow. I mean, this gets very crude, George, you know what I mean? It puts a strain on friendship.
Good afternoon, Mr. Brownlow.
Oh, hello sir. How's Lady Ann?
She's very lucky. I've bought her a present. I was wondering if I could put it in your safe and come back for it later?
Doesn't tick, does it?
Only in wet weather.
This an interrogation, George?
You know me, Toby.
Sure I know you. You want matches so you can burn my feet?
[Esterhase and his men have sidled up to Gregoriev in a public park]

The old city of Thun is not sufficiently appreciated, I believe, by members of our distinguished diplomatic community here. In my view it is to be recommended both for its antiquity, and its banking facilities. Do you not agree?
You'd think a man making his deathbed confession would have the grace to keep it brief, wouldn't you, but oh no... not our Kirov.
Are you a burglar, dearie?
I'm afraid not. Just a visitor.
Still, it's nice to fancied, isn't it dearie?
Very gratifying. Thank you.
Other people sell ties, I sell sex.
I have an alibi for every day of the year hiding from my bank manager.
I'm afraid Vladi's disappeared for good, William. It's in the papers. He's been shot dead. The police will want to ask you questions. I have to hear what happened and tell you how to answer them.

Bozhémoy! For the others, I give nothing. For Vladi, everything. I love this man. After the death of my father, Vladi become father to me. Sometimes I even say him, "my father". Not "Uncle". "Father".
Was Soviets, Max, was Soviet spies! They kill Vladimir! He know too much.
So do you. So do we all.
And the safety signal? The signal which says "I am not being followed".
Was Hamburg newspaper from yesterday.
Oh, Bill. Bill, you stupid bloody fool.
[she walks away]
I mean why didn't they just put it in the bloody post, whatever it is, and be done with it?
You do not buy photographs from Otto Leipzig, you don't buy Degas from Signor Benati, you follow me?

[about the photo of Kirov]
This was not business. This was friendship.

I ask him, "Vladimir, who knows I do this for you?" "Only Mikhel, a very little," he said. "Mikhel is my friend. But even to friends, we cannot trust." "Enemies I do not fear," he said, "but friends, I fear greatly."
God, how I hate autumn.
How's...?
Abandoned me, dammit. Ran off with her pesky riding instructor, blast it. Left me with the children. Oh, the girls are all farmed out to boarding school, thank God!
I'm sorry.
I don't see why should you be? Not your wife.
What do you want me to do?
I want you to bury him, in both senses. I want you to pour oil on the waters, not muddy them.

[deliberately]
Tell me what you want me to do, Oliver.

It's what I don't want you to do. He was a man with an obsession. So were you once. You know who his buddies are, who he hunted with. Speak to them. If there's any milk been spilt, I trust you to get it back into the bottle. You're his executor, George. Tidy him up. Keep us out of it. And don't wander.
George, do you think we set our women up too high? Is that where we English middle-class chaps go wrong?
It may be, Oliver, yes.

Well, if it isn't, then why does Val always fall for shits? We were always taught that women were to be cherished. That if we didn't make them feel loved every moment of the day, they'd go off the rails! This chap Val's with, she annoys him, speaks out of turn! It's mad that he hasn't given her a black eye! You and I never do that.
